official-title.#text:
To amend the Public Health Service Act to provide grants
		  for treatment of heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine,
		  3,4-methylenedioxymethamphet­amine (ecstasy), and phency­clidine (PCP) abuse,
		  and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#text: Mr. Ben Ray Luján of New Mexico
Ms. Eddie Bernice Johnson of Texas

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Access to Substance Abuse Treatment
			 Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
It is the purpose of this Act to—

reduce crime and improve public safety by
			 making treatment for heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine,
			 3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine (ecstasy), and phen­cy­cli­dine (PCP)
			 abuse available to every American who needs it;

help identify root causes and most
			 effective treatment methods for heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine,
			 3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine, and phen­cy­cli­dine abuse; and

expand research into cutting-edge treatment
			 methods for stimulant abuse.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Subpart 1 of part B of title V of the Public
			 Health Service Act

Heroin, cocaine,

provide training and education to substance

header.#text:
Heroin,
				cocaine, methamphetamine, ecstasy, and PCP abuse treatment vouchers for
				underserved populations

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may
				make grants to State, local, and tribal governments and nonprofit entities to
				provide vouchers to individuals in underserved populations for authorized
				services related to the treatment of such individuals for heroin, cocaine,
				methamphetamine, 3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine (ecstasy), and
				phen­cy­cli­dine (PCP) abuse.

internal-xref.#tail:
, a State, local, or tribal
				government or a nonprofit entity shall submit an application to the Secretary
				at such time, in such manner, and containing such information and assurances as
				the Secretary may require, including a description of the method that such
				State, government, or entity will use—

text.#text:
to identify if
				such individuals are in underserved populations; and

to provide
				vouchers to such individuals in such populations.

A recipient of a grant
				under this section may not restrict the ability of an individual receiving a
				voucher under this section to use the voucher to pay for authorized services
				furnished by any provider of authorized services, so long as the provider of
				such services meets all applicable State licensure or certification
				requirements regarding the provision of such services.

With respect to a grant under this section, the period
				during which payments under such grant are made to the grant recipient may not
				exceed five years.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may
				require that recipients of grants under this section provide non-Federal
				matching funds, as determined appropriate by the Secretary, to ensure the
				commitment of the grant recipients to the provision of vouchers for treatment
				to individuals who use heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine,
				3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine, or phen­cy­cli­dine. Such non-Federal
				matching funds may be provided directly or through donations from public or
				private entities and may be in cash or in-kind, fairly evaluated, including
				property, equipment, or services.

may
				require that grant recipients under this section agree to maintain expenditures
				of non-Federal amounts for authorized services related to the treatment of
				heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine, 3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine, and
				phen­cy­cli­dine abuse at a level that is not less than the level of such
				expenditures maintained by the recipient for the fiscal year preceding the
				fiscal year for which the entity receives such a grant.
shall submit a report to the

in improving access to heroin, cocaine,

				treatment for underserved populations.

header.#text:
Heroin, cocaine,
				methamphetamine, 3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine, or
				phen­cy­cli­dine-affected individual

term.#text:
heroin,
				cocaine, methamphetamine, 3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine, or
				phen­cy­cli­dine-affected individual

text.#text:
resided in a residential inpatient
				treatment facility for the treatment of heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine,
				3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine, or phen­cy­cli­dine abuse or addiction;
				or

received treatment for heroin, cocaine,
				methamphetamine, 3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine, or phen­cy­cli­dine
				abuse or addiction from an intensive outpatient treatment facility; and

after successful
				completion of such treatment reenters the community.

term.#tail:
means a facility that provides treatment for
				substance abuse and that, with respect to an individual receiving such
				treatment—

text.#text:
provides a minimum of seven hours of
				treatment for substance abuse during a week;

provides regularly
				scheduled treatment sessions within a structured program; and

ensures that the
				treatment sessions are led by health professionals or clinicians.

term.#tail:
means a facility that provides treatment for
				substance abuse in which health professionals and clinicians provide a planned
				regimen of 24-hour professionally directed evaluation, care, and treatment for
				such substance abuse in an inpatient setting, including 24-hour observation and
				monitoring.

means, with respect to a heroin, cocaine,
				methamphetamine, 3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine, or
				phen­cy­cli­dine-affected individual, the following services:

text.#text:
Prevention services for family members,
				with respect to heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine,
				3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine, and phen­cy­cli­dine abuse or
				addiction.

Transportation
				assistance services for purposes of participation in the services listed in

header.#text:
GAO Evaluation of
			 the impact of this legislation

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Comptroller General of the United
			 States

header.#text:
Study on the
			 level of funding for treatment

text.#text:
the impact of the programs authorized by
			 this Act (including the amendments made by this Act) on the effectiveness and
			 availability of treatment for heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine,
			 3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine, and phen­cy­cli­dine abuse;

whether the level of Federal funding
			 available for the treatment of heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine,
			 3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine, and phen­cy­cli­dine abuse meets,
			 exceeds, or is less than the amount necessary to provide adequate treatment for
			 such abuse; and

the impact of effective treatment of
			 heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine, 3,4-methylene­dioxy­meth­am­phet­amine, and
			 phen­cy­cli­dine abuse on cost savings due to the reduced need for criminal
			 justice and other services.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a report on the interim findings of the study under
